docs.lead_paragraph: It is obvious from even a cursory look at history that doctors sometimes act with prejudice. Consider that as recently as the early 1960's, before major civil rights and Medicare legislation, black women were housed in separate maternity wards. Or that 10 years ago, in some places, AIDS patients could not find a surgeon. Fortunately, blatant discrimination has declined in American medicine, as in other sectors of American life. But bias persists in subtle, more camouflaged forms.

headline.main: Hidden in the World of Medicine, Discrimination and Stereotypes

docs.lead_paragraph: Only recently have doctors and researchers begun thinking of autoimmune syndromes as a kind of boxed set, rather than as a series of distinct disorders. And in some families, it seems, a predisposition to autoimmunity is a box packed by Pandora. Sarah Ciambrone, 47, a manager of a medical clinic for the homeless in Boston, is hard-working, fit, spirited and renowned among local immunologists for the extent of her family hex. Ms. Ciambrone's mother had Graves' thyroiditis in her late 20's -- an autoimmune disorder in which the thyroid gland becomes wildly overactive. One of Sarah's older brothers also came down with Graves' disease in his late 20's, and Sarah soon followed, turning hyperthyroid at the age of 23. Recently, she learned that one of her young maternal cousins had to be treated for Graves'. A maternal uncle has vitiligo, an autoimmune condition that destroys patches of pigment cells in the skin.

docs.lead_paragraph: People wondering if their chronic sleepiness is a sign of a serious sleep disorder can go to one of more than 90 Web sites that offer a brief, simple questionnaire. The only problem, according to a study by researchers at the University of Michigan Health System, is that the test by itself is not considered to provide accurate clues for diagnosis.

docs.lead_paragraph: Whether it's through drinking too hard or driving too fast, or picking fights with fists or pistols, men as a rule are said to engage in more self-destructive behaviors than women. But why should women bother, when their bodies so often do the self-destructing for them?

headline.main: Researchers Piecing Together Autoimmune Disease Puzzle

docs.abstract: Researchers are just beginning to understand why women are far more vulnerable than men to long and varied list of autoimmune diseases, in which body's immune system attacks one or more of body's organs; conditions range from cosmetically annoying to debilitating to severe, progressive and even fatal; one factor seems to be exchange of body cells during pregnancy between mother and fetus; researchers are also devising novel ways to block misguided attacks and let scapegoated organs heal; efforts include new study led by Denise L Faustman in which mice were cured of Type 1 diabetes with injections of drug that induces body to produce tumor necrosis factor, which in turn caused aberrant autoimmune cells to self-destruct and let islet cells of pancreas regrow; diagrams; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Journal of the American Academy of Dermatology kicked off beach season with two studies on sunburn. One suggests that a good way to avoid that red-all-over-look is to wear a T-shirt dyed blue. Researchers at the New York University medical school examined the protection against ultraviolet rays afforded by cotton shirts and how it can be enhanced.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ask the millions of parents whose children have had the hereditary skin condition eczema and many will report that the first ''trick'' their babies learned was how to scratch the intensely itchy lesions against the crib sheets. Some will even say that the itchiness kept their babies from sleeping through the night. Beyond such reports, you're likely to hear what Dr. Herbert P. Goodheart, a New York expert on the condition, might call a myth -- that the baby is reacting allergically to milk-based formula or some other food that must be eliminated from the child's diet. Another common belief that he considers erroneous is that exposure to water (as in baths) should be limited.

headline.main: For Eczema Sufferers, New Relief and Old Myths

docs.lead_paragraph: How aggressively to treat cancer in the elderly is a difficult question, but researchers from the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan who reviewed data on chemotherapy for colon cancer patients suggest that caution may be overdone. In an article published in the June issue of The Journal of the National Cancer Institute, researchers found that the rate at which patients were offered a ''potentially curative'' treatment after surgery for Stage 3 cancer declined ''precipitously'' after age 75.

headline.main: Fewer Options for Older Cancer Patients

docs.abstract: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center study finds rate at which colon cancer patients were offered 'potentially curative' chemotherapy treatment after surgery for Stage 3 colon cancer fell sharply after age 75; finds uncertainty among doctors about whether or not benefits outweigh treatment risks among very old, particularly since relatively few elderly people are included in clinical trials of cancer treatments (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A study published this month in The British Medical Journal posed a simple question: ''Do doctors position defibrillation paddles correctly?'' The answer was apparently not. In defibrillation, a familiar procedure to viewers of television shows set in hospitals, an electric shock is sent between two paddles and through the chest to shock a stalled or stuttering heart back into a healthy rhythm. The paddles usually deliver the current through pads placed on the chest to increase conduction. To be effective, the pads must be placed so the electricity is traveling along a route that includes ''a critical mass'' of heart tissue, say the researchers, from the Southampton General Hospital in England.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mothers may or may not be able to teach their babies French in the womb, but they apparently can help them develop a taste for carrots by drinking carrot juice during pregnancy, an article in the current issue of Pediatrics reports. On the other hand, the researchers also found that mothers could get the same head start on building a healthy palate by breast-feeding and drinking carrot juice.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Dana Wechsler Linden and Emma Trenti Paroli exchanged nervous glances in a neonatal intensive care unit, they never expected that they would be embarking on a four-year career journey together. They met nearly five years ago when their newborns were roommates in a New York City hospital. The two women commiserated about the anxiety and loneliness that parents of preemies sometimes experience.
